importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The start date of the Paris Climate Agreement, marking a pivotal moment in global climate policy where commitments to reduce emissions were formally adopted.
The start of the period used for baseline climate comparison (1991–2020), defining the statistical normal for temperature comparisons in the study.
The year projected for future climate scenarios, used to model long-term impacts of warming on superhot days.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which the study projects the continuation of climate change impacts, particularly the annual increase in superhot days due to warming.

keyTakeAways: The world will experience an additional 57 superhot days annually by 2100 due to climate change, even under current emission commitments.
This represents a significant but reduced impact compared to the worst-case scenario of 114 superhot days under pre-Paris warming trajectories.
Since 2015, the planet has already seen an average of 11 extra superhot days per year.
Small, ocean-dependent nations like Panama, the Solomon Islands, and Samoa face disproportionate increases in heat exposure, with Panama projected to gain 149 extra superhot days annually.
In contrast, top carbon-emitting countries such as the United States, China, and India face only 23–30 extra superhot days despite being responsible for 42% of global CO2 emissions.
The study reveals a severe global inequity in climate impacts, where low-emitting, vulnerable nations suffer disproportionately from heat exposure.
Experts warn that this climate injustice could fuel geopolitical tensions and deepen inequalities between rich and poor nations.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A new study by World Weather Attribution and Climate Central finds that even under current climate commitments, the planet will experience 57 additional superhot days annually by 2100 — nearly two months of dangerously high temperatures — due to climate change. This is a significant improvement from the pre-Paris scenario of 114 superhot days, but still represents a dangerous future. The study reveals a stark global inequity: small, ocean-dependent nations like Panama, the Solomon Islands, and Samoa face massive spikes in heat exposure — with Panama expected to gain 149 extra days — while major emitters such as the United States, China, and India face only 23–30 extra days. Experts emphasize that this disparity not only undermines climate justice but could also contribute to geopolitical instability, as vulnerable nations suffer disproportionately despite contributing little to emissions.
title: Climate study finds overheating world will add 57 superhot days a year
